questions.question: Which of the following is not a goal of the National Health Mission?

options.D: Reduce the incidence of leprosy to half.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D)Reduce the incidence of leprosy to half. Explanation: The National Health Mission, which includes the National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) and the National Urban Health Mission (NUHM), was launched in 2013. The components of NHM: Goals of NHM: Reduce Infant Mortality Rate to 25/1000 live births (Option C) . Reduce Maternal Mortality Rate to 1/1000 live births (Option B) . Reduce Total Fertility Rate to 2.1 Reduce annual incidence and mortality from TB by half. Reduce prevalence of Leprosy to <1/10000 population and incidence to zero in all districts (Option D) . Annual malaria incidence to < 1/1000. <1% microfilaria prevalence in all districts. Eliminate kala-azar by 2015 (Option A) Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no512

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of RMNCAH+N?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Geriatric health Explanation: Reproductive, maternal, newborn, child, and Adolescent Health (RMNCAH+N) is a component of the National Health Mission, launched in 2013. Components of RMNCAH+N: Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/5x5_matrix_2502.pdf Image: https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/maternal-health/guidelines/5x5_matrix_2502.pdf

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding Janani Suraksha Yojana?

options.C: Incentives are provided only to pregnant females delivering in institutions
options.D: It subsidizes the cost of C-sections up to Rs.1500.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Incentives are provided only to pregnant females delivering in institutions mortality by promoting deliveries at health institutions (Option B) . Incentives are provided to both pregnant women and ASHA workers (Option C) : Category Rural areas Urban areas Mother’s incentive ASHA’s incentive Mother’s incentive ASHA’s incentive Low-performing states (LPS) 1400 600 1000 400 High-performing states (HPS) 700 600 600 400 States under LPS: Uttar Pradesh, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Jharkhand, Bihar, Rajasthan, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Assam And Jammu & Kashmir, In LPS, all pregnant women delivering in Govt. Health centers and accredited private hospitals are given incentives irrespective of no. of deliveries. In HPS, below poverty line/SC/ST women delivering in Govt. Health centers and accredited private hospitals are given incentives and are limited to 2 live births. JSY subsidizes the cost of C-section and obstetric complications up to Rs.1500 (Option D) All BPL women delivering at home get an incentive of Rs.500, irrespective of number of deliveries, ASHA gets no incentive for home delivery ,as the government policies prioritize institutional deliveries for safety. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg no: 521.

questions.question: Which of the following health programmes does the logo below represent?
questions.explanation: Karyakram (JSSK) was launched in 2011 to reduce out-of-pocket expenditures for pregnant women and infants up to one year of age. Amenities: Free Delivery (up to 3 days for normal deliveries and up to 7 days for C-section), Diagnostics, Drugs, Blood, Transport and Diet (3 days for normal and 7 days for C-section). Maa Programme (Option A) , to promote breastfeeding. LAQSHYA (Option B) , to promote improved care in delivery services in the labour room and maternal OTs applicable from CHC (Community Health Centres) and above , including District Hospitals (DHs), Medical Colleges , and high-load facilities. Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (Option C) to promote newborn well-being and infant immunization.Under PMMVY 2.0, women who are pregnant for the first time and deliver a live birth are eligible to receive a cash benefit of I 6,000 in two installments, disbursed through Anganwadi Centers (AWCs) and select health facilities

questions.question: Under the LaQshya scheme, what is the focus area for improving infrastructure in healthcare facilities?

options.D: Labour rooms and maternity operation theatres

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Labour rooms and maternity operation theatres Explanation: LAQSHYA is a labour room quality improvement initiative under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare that focuses on improving labour rooms and maternity operation theaters in public health facilities. LAQSHYA (LaborRoom Quality Improvement Initiatives): Aim Improved care in the delivery services in the labor room and ensuring the satisfaction of beneficiaries. Incentive For providing labor room care and ensuring the satisfaction of beneficiaries. Provided to health care setups - CHC, Sub-district hospital and District hospital. Sub centers and PHC are not a part of LAQSHYA. 80% satisfied beneficiaries will be provided incentives of: Rs. 6 lakhs: For Medical College hospitals Rs. 3 lakhs: District hospitals Rs. 2 Lakhs: First referral units NQAS score Platinum- 90% Gold- 80% Silver- 70% Dakshata Scheme: Objective : Improve maternal and newborn care quality, focusing on institutional childbirth. Main Objectives : Enhance Provider Competency : Train labor room staff (medical officers, nurses, ANMs) in evidence-based practices. Transfer of Learning : Implement strategies to boost adherence to clinical protocols. Improve Supplies : Ensure availability of essential resources in labor rooms and postpartum wards. Accountability : Strengthen data recording, reporting, and utilization to track service provider performance. MNH Toolkit : Implement the Maternal and Newborn Health Toolkit at delivery points. Pillars : Multi-pronged approach to standardize clinical competencies and create a supportive environment for quality care during childbirth and immediate postpartum periods.

questions.question: Which maternal health initiative is not under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Pradhan mantri matru vandana yojana Explanation: Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana falls under the Ministry of Women and Child Development (MWCD) Other schemes under MWCD ICDS SABLA PMMVY UJAWALA (to prevent trafficking of women and children) Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (Option A) This program is under the Ministry of Women and Child Development. Cash incentive is given only up to 1 birth. Cash incentive of Rs. 6000 given in 2 installments: First Installment : I 3,000 is given after the beneficiary registers her pregnancy and meets early antenatal care conditions, such as taking iron-folic acid tablets and receiving the first tetanus toxoid injection. Second Installment : I 3,000 is provided after delivery, following birth registration and initial immunization of the newborn with vaccines such as BCG, OPV, and Hepatitis Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan (Option B) On the 9th of every month, free antenatal services are provided to women, particularly in the 2nd or 3rd trimester, in government and private facilities that are part of the scheme. Aim - To identify high-risk pregnancies on time. This program is under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Red card - Women at high risk. Green card - Women at no risk Blue card - Woman is a case of PIH Yellow card - Women with comorbidities (Diabetes, Thyroid) Surakshit Matritva Aashwasan (SUMAN) Scheme (Option C) This is also under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Initiative: Zero preventable maternal and newborn deaths. Beneficiaries: Pregnant women during the antenatal period Women during delivery Women up to 6 months post-delivery Sick neonates Total number of services provided- 18 Maa Programme (Mother's Absolute Affection) (Option D) Aim- To promote breastfeeding. Under the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Functions: Lactation counselling and breastfeeding initiations. Stimulation and expression support through electric breast pumps Collection, storage, processing and dispensing of donor human milk

questions.question: 6x6x6 strategy is related to?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anemia Mukt Bharat Explanation: The 6x6x6 strategy is related to anemia mukt Bharat. It stands for 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms. 6 INTERVENTIONS 6 STRATEGIES Prophylactic iron-folic acid supplementation. Deworming. Intensified year-round behaviour change communication campaign (solid body, smart mind), including ensured delayed cord clamping. Testing of anaemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment. Mandatory provision of iron folic acid fortified foods in public health programmes. Addressing non-nutritional causes of anaemia in endemic pockets with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis. National Anaemia Mukt Bharat Unit. Intra-ministerial coordination. Strengthening supply chain and logistics. Convergence with other ministries. National Centre of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anaemia Control. Anaemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and digital portal- One-stop shop for anaemia. 6 BENEFICIARIES Children, 6-59 months of age (Bi-weekly Administer 1 ml of Iron and Folic Acid syrup containing 20 mg elemental iron and 100 mcg folic acid per dose) Children, 5-9 years of age- pink tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated pink tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 45 mg elemental iron and 400 mcg folic acid) Adolescent girls & boys (10-19 years of age)- blue tablets (Weekly administer one sugar-coated blue tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid) Women of reproductive age group (20-24 years of age).(Weekly, administer one sugar-coated red tablet of Iron and Folic Acid containing 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid) Pregnant women- Red tablets (180 tablets) Daily, 1 Iron and Folic Acid tablet should be taken starting from the fourth month of pregnancy (second trimester) and continued throughout the pregnancy (for at least 180 days ). Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid , is sugar-coated, and red in color. Lactating mothers (of 0-6 months child)- Red tablets .The tablet should also be continued for 180 days post-partum. Each tablet contains 60 mg elemental iron and 500 mcg folic acid , is sugar-coated, and red in color. Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman (Option B) provides meals to school-going children in government schools to decrease school drop-out rate and increase attendance rate.The supplementary nutrition provided under PM POSHAN includes up to half of a child's total protein requirement and one-third of their energy needs, especially in districts with high rates of anemia and malnutrition The 5x5 strategy is seen in RMNCH+A (Option C). It involves five high-impact interventions across five groups: reproductive, maternal, neonatal, child, and adolescent health. Kishori Shakti Yojana (Option D) aims to empower adolescent girls through nutrition and health education. Reference: https://nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=3&sublinkid=1448&lid=797 \ https://pmposhan.education.gov.in/aboutus.html

questions.question: Which international organization collaborated with the Government of India to implement IMNCI?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) World Health Organization (WHO) Explanation: IMNCI, or Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness, was introduced in India by the government of India in collaboration with WHO. IMNCI: IMNCI is an evidence-based strategy developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) and launched in India by the Government of India to reduce childhood mortality and morbidity by improving the quality of health care for children under five years old. Illnesses included: Acute respiratory infections (ARI) like Pneumonia Diarrhea 3 M’s - Measles, malaria, malnutrition. Otitis Media Reference: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/7091371954Mod%201%20INTRODUCTION%20R.pdf http s://www.who.int/teams/maternal-newborn-child-adolescent-health-and-ageing/child-health/integrated-management- of-childhood-illness https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/programmes/child-health/guidelines/imnci_chart_booklet.pdf

questions.question: At what age are children screened under the RBSK program?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 0-18 years Explanation: Children from age 0 to 18 years are screened under the RBSK program. RBSK Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram: RBSK Launched in 2013. Relies on early childhood screening and interventional services. Referral Unit/ Early intervention centre - District hospital Age group 0-6 years- urban or rural slums 6-18 years- government school-going children Screening Secondary level of prevention Screening done for 4Ds: Diseases Defects Deficiencies Developmental delays Referral unit- District hospital Screened by Mobile teams and this includes: Medical officers Ayush officers Pharmacists Lab technicians 4D’s: Defects at birth Deficiencies Neural tube defects Down's syndrome Talipes (club foot) Developmental dysplasia of the hip Congenital cataract Congenital deafness Congenital heart diseases Anemia Vitamin A deficiency (Bitot spot) Vitamin D deficiency (rickets) Severe Acute malnutrition Goitre Diseases of childhood Development delay Skin conditions(scabies, fungal and eczema) Otitis media Rheumatic heart disease Reactive airway disease Dental conditions Convulsive disorders Vision impairment Hearing Impairment Neuromotor impairment Motor delay Cognitive delay Language delay Behavior disorder Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder Sickle cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, Congenital hypothyroidism Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, pg 529 https://nhm.gov.in/index4.php?lang=1&level=0&linkid=499&lid=773

questions.question: Which of the following is a specific objective of Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (NSSK)?

options.B: To increase access to prenatal care for expecting mothers.
options.C: To improve sanitation facilities in rural healthcare centers.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) To prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related mortality. Explanation: NSSK aims to reduce India's Neonatal Mortality Rate, aligning with global health targets, emphasizing improved newborn health outcomes and reduced mortality from conditions like perinatal asphyxia. Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram(NSSK) A training program launched by the Indian Government to equip doctors and nurses with essential newborn care skills, specifically addressing birth asphyxia. Training program for medical officers (MOs) and auxiliary nurse-midwives (ANMs) is two days long The ultimate goal is to reduce newborn mortality and morbidity. Goals/Objectives Reduce Neonatal Mortality Rate: Decrease India's Neonatal Mortality Rate to single digits by 2030. Improve Newborn Care Quality: Enhance the quality of newborn care. Prevent Perinatal Asphyxia-Related Issues: Reduce morbidity and mortality linked to perinatal asphyxia. Strategies Capacity Building : Equip healthcare providers with necessary knowledge and skills. Essential Newborn Care and Resuscitation Training. Updated Curriculum and Training Methodology Standardized Equipment and Supplies : Provide clean, functional equipment. Effective Knowledge and Skill Transfer : Improve practical application of training. Focus on "Golden Minute" : Quick assessment and resuscitation. Promoting Clean Birth Practices: Adhere to WHO's "six cleans". Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC). Promotion: Encourage KMC for low birth weight babies. Timely Immunization : Ensure vaccination before discharge. Educate parents on newborn care. Effective Neonatal Transport : Establish protocols for the safe transport of sick newborns.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of the India Newborn Action Plan (INAP)?

options.A: To achieve universal healthcare coverage by 2030.
options.B: To reduce neonatal mortality rate to single digits by 2030.
options.C: To eliminate maternal mortality completely by 2030.
options.D: To increase vaccination coverage for children under 5 years old.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) To reduce neonatal mortality rate to single digits by 2030. Explanation: INAP's primary objective is to achieve a neonatal mortality rate of less than 10 deaths per 1,000 live births by 2030. The India Newborn Action Plan (INAP) INAP, launched in June 2014, is a targeted strategy designed to reduce preventable newborn deaths and stillbirths in India. Developed in response to the global Every Newborn Action Plan (ENAP), INAP identifies evidence-based interventions to lower newborn and maternal mortality rates. Objectives and Goals Strategies to Achieve Goals Single Digit Neonatal Mortality Rate by 2030: Achieve <10 deaths per 1,000 live births. Stillbirth Rate by 2030: Target <10 stillbirths per 1,000 total births. RMNCH+A Framework: Implement within the existing healthcare framework. Six Intervention Packages : Cover all life stages of newborns. Preconception and antenatal care Care during labor and childbirth Immediate newborn care Care of the healthy newborn Care of the small and sick newborn Care beyond newborn survival Strategic Intervention Packages : Categorize interventions as essential, situational, and advanced. State-Specific Action Plans: Encourage tailored plans based on intervention packages. High Intervention Coverage : To prevent a significant proportion of newborn deaths, stillbirths, and maternal deaths by 2025. Monitoring and Evaluation : Systematic tracking and dashboard indicators for progress. Comprehensive Assessment : Conduct a thorough evaluation in 2020 to inform future strategies. Periodic Reviews : Review milestones every five years aligned with ENAP timelines.

questions.question: What is the primary focus area of the Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram?

options.A: Reproductive and sexual health education only.
options.B: Comprehensive health care along with reproductive and sexual health.
options.C: Exclusive focus on non-communicable disease prevention.
options.D: Augmentation of facility-based services for maternal health.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Comprehensive health care along with reproductive and sexual health. Launched in January 2014, this initiative targets 253 million adolescents across India in their own environments. It introduces peer-led interventions within communities, complemented by improved facility-based services. The initiative expands the scope of adolescent health beyond reproductive and sexual health. Target Group Adolescents 10-19 years of age in Urban and rural areas Focus Girls and Boys; Married and Unmarried; In School and Out of school 7 Critical Components (7Cs) Coverage Content Communities Clinics Counseling Communication 6 Strategic Priorities Nutrition Sexual and reproductive health (SRH) Non-communicable diseases (NCDs) Substance misuse Injuries and violence(+ gender-based violence) Mental health-Peer Education Programme plays a key role in addressing adolescent health issues through trained Peer Educators, called "Saathiyas. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition,page 517 https://www.jknhm.com/rksk.php

questions.question: Which of the following is the comprehensive program the Ministry of Women and Child Development launched to combat trafficking?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ujjawala scheme Explanation: The Ujjawala scheme The Ujjawala scheme, launched in India on December 4, 2007, by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, is a comprehensive program to combat trafficking. The scheme is primarily implemented through NGOs. Objectives/Goals Strategies to Achieve Goals Prevention Formation of community vigilance and adolescent groups, awareness creation preparation of IEC (Information, Education, Communication) material, organization of workshops. Rescue Safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation. Rehabilitation Providing safe shelter, basic amenities, medical care, legal aid, vocational training, and employment opportunities to victims. Reintegration Supporting victims in their reintegration into society. Repatriation Providing support to cross-border victims for their safe return to their home countries. The Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY) (Option B) is a key initiative to provide rural and underprivileged households with access to clean cooking fuels like LPG, replacing traditional cooking fuels. It comes under the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas (MOPNG) The UJALA (Unnat Jyoti by Affordable LEDs for All) scheme (Option C) aims to promote energy efficiency by distributing LED bulbs at affordable prices. This initiative reduces energy consumption and lowers household electricity bills. It also contributes to environmental sustainability by cutting down carbon emissions. The Ministry of Power administers it. The PM Sahaj Bijli Har Ghar Yojana (PM Saubhagya scheme)(Option D) was initiated in September 2017 to provide electricity to every household by December 2018. The Ministry of Power administers it.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key activity under the Menstrual Hygiene Scheme?

options.A: Community-based health education and outreach to promote menstrual health.
options.B: Providing free school uniforms to adolescent girls.
options.C: Ensuring regular availability of sanitary napkins to adolescents.
options.D: Training of ASHA and nodal teachers in menstrual health.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Providing free school uniforms to adolescent girls. Explanation: Menstrual Hygiene Scheme: Objective : Promotion of menstrual hygiene among adolescent girls aged 10-19 years in rural areas. Aims: To ensure girls have adequate knowledge and information about menstrual hygiene. Provide access to high-quality sanitary napkins and safe disposal mechanisms. Key Activities: Community-Based Health Education and Outreach for Promoting menstrual health in the target population (Option A) . Availability of Sanitary Napkins regularly to adolescents (Option C) . Sourcing and Procuring sanitary napkins. Storage and Distribution of sanitary napkins to adolescent girls. Train ASHA and nodal teachers in menstrual health (Option D) . Implement safe disposal mechanisms for sanitary napkins. Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th ed Pg 533
